TEXT: The applicant , PERSON , was a NORP national who was born in DATE and lived in PERSON . On DATE the applicant ’s grandson , Mr PERSON , represented by PERSON , a lawyer practising in PERSON , informed the Registry that the applicant had died in DATE .
The respondent Government were represented by their Agent , Mr J. Wołąsiewicz of ORG .
The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

On DATE the applicant ’s husband died in a car accident . CARDINAL cars ( a ORG , a ORG and the deceased ’s car ) were found to be involved in the accident . Soon after the accident police officers came to the scene and made an inspection of the locus in quo . The deceased ’s identity documents were found . A death certificate was issued by a doctor . On DATE the deceased ’s car was transported to FAC parking site . The body was taken to a private funeral parlour which did not have a cold storage chamber . On DATE after the accident it was transported to a forensic police unit with a cold storage chamber .

On DATE the applicant , who had made inquiries as she had become increasingly worried when her husband had failed to return home on time , was informed by the Wrocław Regional District Station that no car accidents had been recorded in the region on DATE . LOC gave her the same information .
On DATE , DATE after the accident , the applicant was informed of her husband ’s death .

In a decision of the District Prosecutor given on an unspecified date in the proceedings instituted by the applicant for the failure to inform her speedily of her husband ’s death , it was stated that the lack of information had been the result of poor coordination between the police stations .
On DATE an autopsy was conducted at ORG at ORG . On DATE a blood test was carried out which showed that the deceased had QUANTITY of alcohol in his blood .

On DATE , by a decision of ORG , the investigation into the death of the applicant ’s husband was prolonged until DATE as further measures had to be taken ( including the obtaining of an expert opinion on traffic accidents and the questioning of further witnesses ) .
On DATE , DATE after the blood test had been carried out , the results were lodged with ORG .
On DATE , by a decision of ORG , the investigation was prolonged until DATE since the expert opinion had not yet been obtained . On DATE the inquest proceedings were again prolonged until DATE .
On DATE the applicant learned from the forensic expert appointed in the case the result of the blood test conducted on DATE .

On DATE the applicant requested that a further blood test be conducted . On DATE FAC gave a decision ordering a new blood test to be carried out . The test was conducted on DATE . Its results were different from those of DATE as the new examination showed that there had been QUANTITY of alcohol in the deceased ’s blood . Both examinations relied on the same blood samples taken on DATE .
On DATE ORG sent a letter to ORG explaining that the different results of the tests had been caused by a mistake in copying the results from CARDINAL medical document to another .
On DATE the applicant instituted criminal proceedings alleging that the results of the forensic tests had been forged .
On DATE the proceedings were discontinued by a decision of ORG . It was found that no criminal offence had been committed in connection with the forensic tests . The applicant appealed .
On DATE ORG upheld the decision . The applicant appealed .

On DATE the ORG quashed the decision and remitted the case to the prosecutor with a view to obtaining a supplementary opinion of an expert in graphology . Nevertheless , the prosecution authorities did not order such an opinion to be prepared and the applicant ’s subsequent request to that effect was refused .

On DATE ORG again discontinued the proceedings as the error was found to have been unintentional and as such could not constitute the offence of forgery . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG upheld the decision .
On DATE the applicant lodged a private bill of indictment with the court against persons who , in her opinion , had been negligent in the preparation of the results of the blood tests .
On DATE the ORG discontinued the proceedings , finding that no criminal offence had been committed . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG upheld the decision .
The applicant was a party to these proceedings as she had the status of a victim in the investigation and that of auxiliary prosecutor ( oskarżyciel posiłkowy ) in the judicial proceedings .
On DATE the driver of the ORG was questioned by the police . On DATE he was declared to be suspected of causing death by dangerous driving . On DATE he was questioned again .
On DATE ORG lodged with ORG a bill of indictment charging him with causing death by dangerous driving . In DATE the case was transferred to ORG and subsequently , in DATE , to ORG .
On DATE an expert opinion prepared by PERSON was submitted to the court .

Subsequent hearings were held on DATE and DATE . On the latter date the court decided to conduct the proceedings anew as a new judge rapporteur had been assigned to the case . The hearings were resumed and held on DATE , DATE , DATE , DATE , CARDINAL May , DATE and DATE . On DATE the applicant requested that the case be remitted for further investigation . The request was dismissed by the court on DATE .

On DATE the applicant lodged a hierarchical complaint with the President of the ORG concerning the excessive length of the proceedings . By a letter of DATE the President of the ORG informed the applicant that there were no grounds for finding that the proceedings were too lengthy .

On DATE the applicant challenged the judge rapporteur , a motion which was dismissed on DATE . On DATE the court allowed her motion for another expert opinion to be prepared . The next hearings were held on CARDINAL and DATE and DATE .

On DATE the court allowed the applicant ’s motion for another ( fourth ) expert opinion to be prepared . It was submitted to it on DATE . At a hearing held on DATE the court refused the applicant ’s request for another ( fifth ) opinion .
On DATE the ORG gave a judgment by which it acquitted the accused . Altogether CARDINAL hearings were held before the firstinstance court .
On DATE the applicant appealed .

On DATE the ORG quashed the judgment and remitted the case . It found , inter alia , that the length of proceedings had been excessive as they had lasted DATE . The court pointed out that numerous procedural shortcomings on the part of the firstinstance court had resulted in the erroneous assessment of the evidence . It found that the erroneous decisions taken in the course of the proceedings showed that the court had been unable to obtain a full picture of the circumstances relevant for the assessment of the case . In particular , it had admitted in evidence several expert opinions and later refused the applicant ’s request to summon the experts for questioning . The court had also organised CARDINAL subsequent superfluous hearings during which it only informed the parties that the expert opinions had not yet been obtained . It had also dismissed a request to admit the evidence of new witnesses , without specifying which request and which witnesses it had referred to . ORG further doubted whether one of the experts had had access to the court file , which would have been indispensable for giving his opinion . It also pointed out that although the expert opinions differed substantially , the first - instance court had not ordered the experts to be questioned .
The case was remitted to ORG and QUANTITY hearings were held .

On DATE the ORG stayed the proceedings in order to obtain a new expert opinion . The applicant appealed and her appeal was allowed . The proceedings were resumed on DATE . The new opinion was submitted to the court on DATE .

In DATE hearings were held on CARDINAL and CARDINAL May , DATE and DATE and CARDINAL DATE and CARDINAL DATE . Hearings scheduled for DATE and CARDINAL DATE were adjourned as the experts had failed to comply with the summonses .

On DATE the ORG found the accused guilty of causing death by dangerous driving and sentenced him to DATE imprisonment , suspended conditionally for DATE , and to a fine . On DATE the defendant appealed .

On DATE the ORG quashed the judgment and remitted the case . It found that there were serious discrepancies between the terms of the judgment and its written grounds and that numerous shortcomings of a procedural character had occurred in the proceedings .
CARDINAL hearings were held before ORG after the case had been again remitted .

On DATE the ORG found the accused guilty , sentenced him to DATE imprisonment , suspended conditionally for DATE , to a fine and to the payment of damages to the applicant . Both the applicant and the defendant appealed .

On DATE ORG upheld the first - instance judgment in its part concerning the conviction and the sentence . It quashed the part concerning the payment of damages . It observed that the firstinstance judgment of DATE had not contained any decision concerning compensation as the court had availed itself of the possibility of leaving the civil claim undecided . It had been appealed against by the defendant and was subsequently quashed . In this situation , the firstinstance court , when deciding the case again , could not rule on the compensation claim as this was in breach of the reformationis in peius prohibition .
The applicant was a party to these proceedings having the status of a victim of the offence .
On DATE the driver of the ORG was heard by the police as a witness .

On DATE ORG decided to discontinue the inquest proceedings as he found that although the driver of the ORG had been responsible for the accident , his or her identity had not been established . On DATE the applicant appealed .
On DATE ORG upheld the decision . On CARDINAL DATE the applicant appealed .

On DATE the ORG Appellate PERSON ordered the investigation to be reopened with a view to taking additional investigatory measures , including questioning of further witnesses and obtaining an expert opinion on traffic accidents .
On DATE , by a decision of the police , the investigation was discontinued as the driver of the ORG had not been identified . On DATE the applicant appealed .
On DATE ORG upheld the decision . On DATE the applicant appealed .
On DATE the President of ORG found the applicant ’s appeal inadmissible in law . The applicant appealed . On DATE ORG upheld the contested decision .

Under LAW CARDINAL of the Code of Criminal Procedure , the criminal court shall not decide on a civil claim brought in the criminal proceedings if it finds that the evidence gathered in those proceedings is insufficient to make a ruling and the gathering of such evidence would unduly prolong the proceedings . It is open for the victim of the offence to seek compensation in civil proceedings .
